AUSTIN -- A $3 million registry of educators banned from employment, stiff penalties for superintendents who protect their teachers' misconduct and beefed up training to guard against inappropriate relationships with students are ideas state Senators are considering in reaction to the state's high number of alleged teacher-student sex scandals. 
State lawmakers on Thursday said they will make it a priority to change how schools and districts report and prevent cases of misconduct amid cases throughout the state of teachers and other educators accused of engaging in romantic or sexual relationships with students. 
GROWING PROBLEM IN TEXAS: Texas seeing boom in teacher-student sex scandals 
Several state organizations representing teachers say they support two bills heard in the Senate Education Committee Thursday, and say they look forward to requiring robust training for teachers to navigate student contact amid a social media culture. 
Cases of educator-student relationships have boomed in recent years, resulting in hundreds of teachers losing their licenses amid allegations of misconduct between 2010 and 2016. Lawmakers say they want to ensure teachers with a history of inappropriate relationships are unable to score jobs in other school districts. 
Two different bills have been filed in the Texas State Senate to address the issue: SB7 and SB653.
